prior_works.title: Single World Intervention Graphs (SWIGs): A Unification of the Counterfactual and Graphical Approaches to Causality
prior_works.authors: Thomas S. Richardson, James M. Robins
prior_works.role: Counterfactual graphical semantics and Markov properties
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s two-world construction that separates the world where selection occurs from the world where interventions are applied is directly inspired by SWIG-style counterfactual graph semantics and their associated Markov/separation properties.

prior_works.title: Ancestral Graph Markov Models
prior_works.role: Graphical treatment of selection bias and latent variables via MAGs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By explicitly modeling selection variables and characterizing their induced independences in MAGs, this work provides the foundational machinery for handling selection bias that the present paper extends to interventional settings.

prior_works.title: Characterization and Greedy Algorithms for Learning Interventional Markov Equivalence Classes of Directed Acyclic Graphs
prior_works.role: Interventional Markov equivalence (I-MEC) and structure learning from interventions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The new model generalizes interventional Markov properties by incorporating selection mechanisms, showing how ignoring selection invalidates I-MEC reasoning established in this work.

prior_works.title: Recovering from Selection Bias in Causal and Statistical Inference
prior_works.authors: Elias Bareinboim, Jin Tian, Judea Pearl
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors build on selection-diagram reasoning to analyze identifiability under selection, adapting these ideas from effect estimation to the causal discovery setting with interventions.

prior_works.title: Causation, Prediction, and Search (2nd ed.)
prior_works.authors: Peter Spirtes, Clark Glymour, Richard Scheines
prior_works.role: Algorithmic foundations (FCI) for discovery with latent confounding and selection bias
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Insights about how selection variables induce spurious associations in discovery algorithms motivate the paper’s explicit handling of selection when learning from interventional data.

prior_works.title: Joint Causal Inference from Multiple Contexts
prior_works.authors: Sara Magliacane, Joris M. Mooij, Tom Claassen, Jonas Peters, Philip L. H. Steeg, et al. (various versions)
prior_works.role: Unified modeling of interventions and contexts
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By encoding where and when interventions occur through context variables, JCI anticipates the importance of modeling intervention regimes; the present paper refines this by separating pre-intervention selection from post-intervention data-generating worlds.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core innovation—explicitly separating a pre-intervention selection world from the post-intervention observed world within a unified graphical framework—sits at the confluence of counterfactual graph semantics, selection-aware graphical models, and interventional causal discovery. The counterfactual formalism of SWIGs (Richardson & Robins, 2013) directly underpins the two-world representation and its Markov/separation properties, enabling principled reasoning about variables that would have been measured prior to intervention. On the selection side, ancestral graph theory (Richardson & Spirtes, 2002) and the treatment of selection nodes in discovery algorithms (Spirtes, Glymour & Scheines, 2000) provide the canonical account of how conditioning on selection distorts independences—insights that the present paper extends to settings where interventions are administered only within a selected subpopulation.

Interventional discovery advances, especially the characterization of interventional Markov equivalence (Hauser & Bühlmann, 2012), are a key foil: the authors show that standard I-MEC reasoning breaks when selection is ignored and then re-derive appropriate equivalence/Markov properties in their new graph. From the identifiability perspective, selection diagrams and recoverability criteria (Bareinboim, Tian & Pearl, 2014) inform the paper’s graph-theoretic analysis of when causal structure remains discoverable despite selection. Finally, multi-environment frameworks like Joint Causal Inference (Magliacane et al., 2018) motivate the explicit encoding of intervention regimes (“where/when” interventions occur); the present work sharpens this by introducing a counterfactual pre-intervention layer to disentangle selection from intervention effects. Together, these strands enable a coherent theory and algorithms for interventional causal discovery under selection bias.
